text: The coordinative assembly of metal−organic coordination frameworks (MOFs) based on transition metals and organic spacers attracts much attention.

The ability to control the polymorph formation and crystal shape is very important in crystal engineering. The solvent is a critical parameter influencing the formation of MOFs; typically, water, alcohols, ketones, esters, acids, acetates, and alkanes, and their mixtures, are used for this purpose. Because of their different physical and chemical properties, different solvents influence the crystal growth rate and the final morphology. Furthermore, solvents play important roles in polymorphism via solute−solvent interactions.
Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, the component ratio of a mixed solvent has never previously been employed as a controlling factor in determining the ultimate topology of a series of MOFs.

MOFs transform into other MOFs in solvents through a set of complex processes involving dissolution, dissolving, transforming, and crystallizing. This approach is attracting increased interest from chemists because it can sometimes provide intriguing topologies and structural architectures that cannot be obtained through direct synthesis.
Several reports suggest that MOF transformations are also influenced by the ligands chosen, the reaction temperature,

Although the nature of the solvent is, in general, the most critical factor affecting a chemical reaction, we are aware of only a few investigative examples of solvent-controlled MOF transformations. For example, Chung and co-workers reported that a coordination polymer [Co(mpe)
], consisting of two mutually interpenetrating independent three-dimensional (3D) frameworks belonging to CdSO
topology and two-dimensional (2D) square grid layers, transformed into a noninterpenetrating isomeric form when it was immersed in hot water.

Although solvents and mixed solvents have been used for the controlled syntheses of new materials and for studies of the transformations of MOFs, systematic investigations of the effects of the component ratios of mixed solvents on the synthesis of metal−organic complexes and their MOF transformations remain relatively unexplored.
Herein, we present a systematic investigation of how DMF/H
O volume ratios affect the syntheses and transformations of a series of copper(II) complexes constructed using the rigid-angled μ

Atomic absorption spectra were recorded using a SoLAARM6 apparatus from Thermo-Scientific.

The changes in the crystal features of the complexes involve dissolution/dissolving/transforming/crystallizing processes, that is, solution phenomena (Figure
). Therefore, the transformation products are directly related to the solubilities of the complexes. We used atomic absorption analysis to measure the solubilities of
O volume ratios of 9:1, 1:1, 1:9, and 0:1, respectively, consistent with complexes
O volume ratios of 9:1, 1:1, and 0:1, respectively, and also with the complexes always being transformed into
O volume ratios of 9:1, 1:1, 1:9, and 0:1, respectively. Therefore, it appears that the DMF/H
O volume ratio is the decisive factor affecting both the syntheses and transformations of these cobalt complexes.

O solvents of 9:1, 1:1, 1:9, and 0:1 with an increase of the solvent polarity suggest the involvement of solute−solvent interactions, which arise mainly through dipole−dipole interactions between the polar molecules. The polarity of a compound depends on permanent, inductive, and instantaneous dipoles.

The permanent dipole relies on the structural symmetry of a molecule; the inductive polarity is related to the polarizability and polarity of a solvent; the instantaneous polarity depends on the volume of a molecule. Therefore, the instantaneous and inductive polarities of a polymer should be greater than those of a monomer. Furthermore, the greater the solvent’s polarity, the greater the inductive polarity of the resulting complex. The symmetries of complexes
. Therefore, taking all of these factors into consideration, we might expect that the polarities of these four compounds follow the order

O. Obviously, the polarity of a solvent used to dissolve a complex is consistent with its solubility in that solvent (Table
contain 1D channels occupied by crystallographic DMF molecules, but complex

has neither crystallographic DMF nor open channels in its structure. The results suggest that the solvent DMF, as a bigger solvent molecule, functions as a template to guide the formation of porous coordination polymers. Notably, complex
contains no DMF despite its preparation in a DMF/H
O mixed solvent, which may be attributable to host−guest crystallization kinetics.
We have used mixed solvents, comprising various DMF/H

O volume ratios, to control the direct syntheses and conversions of a series of cobalt complexes constructed using the rigid-angled ligand Hdpt24. These direct syntheses and transformations are clearly related to the complexes’ solubilities in their specific formation solvents. In addition, the complexes’ solubilities can be explained in terms of the polarities of the complexes and solvents. Interestingly, we obtained two rare uninodal net NbO-like networks built from a single ligand. We anticipate that this unprecedented approach, varying the component volume ratio of a mixed solvent to control solvothermal syntheses and MOF transformations, might have wide applicability in other crystal engineering processes.

Crystal engineering of acentric diamondoid metal-organic coordination networks
Evans, Owens R.; Xiong, Ren-Gen; Wang, Zhiyong; Wong, George K.; Lin, Wenbin

Acentric polymeric networks based on diamondoid structures were readily constructed by choosing the appropriate unsym. bridging ligands.  The complexes bis(isonicotinato)zinc (1) and bis(trans-4-pyridylacrylato)cadmium monohydrate (2) were prepd. by reacting the metal perchlorates with 4-cyanopyridine and trans-4-pyridylacrylic acid, resp.  1 And 2 were characterized by x-ray crystallog. (1: orthorhombic, space group P212121, R = 0.026; 2: monoclinic, space group Cc, R = 0.039).  Both complexes have acentric diamondoid metal-org. coordination network structures with an odd no. of interpenetrating nets: threefold in 1 and fivefold in 2.  Preliminary second-order nonlinear optical activities of 1 and 2 were consistent with their acentric structures.  Both complexes exhibited remarkable thermal stability.
1D, 2D and 3D coordination polymers of aromatic carboxylate TbIII: structure, thermolysis kinetics and fluorescence
Zhou, Ying-Xia; Shen, Xiao-Qing; Du, Chen-Xia; Wu, Ben-Lai; Zhang, Hong-Yun

Reactions of TbCl3·6H2O with arom. acids, namely, pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2pda), isophthalic acid (H2ipa) and isonicotinic acid (Hina) gave rise to three new coordination polymers {[Tb(pda)(Hpda)]·3H2O}n (1), {[KTb(ipa)2(H2O)3(μ-H2O)]·2H2O}n (2) and [Tb(Ina)3(H2O)2]n (3), resp.  Complex 1, constructed by eight-coordinate TbIII nodes connected with completely and half-deprotonated pda and Hpda spacers, is a novel 3D metal-org. architecture with nanosized hexagonal 1D channels hosting guest water, whereas complex 2 is a 2D heterometal sheet built by completely deprotonated ipa spacers bridging eight-coordinate KI and nine-coordinate TbIII.  As for 3, deprotonated monoacid ina anions link eight-coordinate TbIII centers into a 1D double-chain structure.  Excited at 320 nm, complexes 1-3 all display a series of emissions centered at ∼486, 545, 582 and 620 nm, which is assigned to the characteristic 5D4 → 7Fj (j = 6; 5; 4; 3) electronic transitions of TbIII.  The overall fluorescence nature of 1-3 is extremely alike, but their fluorescence intensity and lifetime are affected by the architectures.  Very interestingly, the fluorescence intensity of 2, esp. emitting at 545 nm, is largely enhanced owing to the coordination of alkali metal KI in the TbIII-carboxylate network.  Furthermore, thermal behaviors of 1-3 under a nitrogen atm. as well as the thermolysis nonisothermal kinetics of 2 are researched.
A Large-Surface-Area Boracite-Network-Topology Porous MOF Constructed from a Conjugated Ligand Exhibiting a High Hydrogen Uptake Capacity
Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Yuan, Daqiang; Yoon, Ji Woong; Hwang, Young Kyu; Chang, Jong-San; Wang, Xiaoping; Jorgensen, Mads Ry; Chen, Yu-Sheng; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A new porous metal-org. framework, [Cu3L3(H2O)3]n (PCN-20) with a twisted boracite net topol., was constructed based on a highly conjugated planar tricarboxylate ligand, triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylic acid (H3L).  The crystal structure of PCN-20 was detd.  PCN-20 possesses a large Langmuir surface area of over 4200 m2/g as well as demonstrates a high hydrogen uptake capacity of 6.2% at 77 K and 50 bar.
High Capacity Hydrogen Adsorption in Cu(II) Tetracarboxylate Framework Materials: The Role of Pore Size, Ligand Functionalization, and Exposed Metal Sites

Lin, Xiang; Telepeni, Irvin; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Brown, Craig M.; Simmons, Jason M.; Zoppi, Marco; Walker, Gavin S.; Thomas, K. Mark; Mays, Timothy J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Isostructural metal-org. framework polymers [Cu2(L)(H2O)2] (L = tetracarboxylate ligands), denoted NOTT-nnn, were synthesized and characterized.  Single crystal x-ray structures confirm the complexes to contain binuclear Cu(II) paddlewheel nodes each bridged by four carboxylate centers to give a NbO-type network of 64·82 topol.  These complexes are activated by solvent exchange with acetone coupled to heating cycles under vacuum to afford the desolvated porous materials NOTT-100 to NOTT-109.  These incorporate a vacant coordination site at each Cu(II) center and have large pore vols. that contribute to the obsd. high H2 adsorption.  Indeed, NOTT-103 at 77 K and 60 bar shows a very high total H2 adsorption of 77.8 mg g-1 equiv. to 7.78% [wt% = (wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material)] or 7.22% [wt% = 100(wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material + wt. of adsorbed H2)].  Neutron powder diffraction studies on NOTT-101 reveal three adsorption sites for this material: at the exposed Cu(II) coordination site, at the pocket formed by three {Cu2} paddle wheels, and at the cusp of three Ph rings.  Systematic virial anal. of the H2 isotherms suggests that the H2 binding energies at these sites are very similar and the differences are smaller than 1.0 kJ mol-1, although the adsorption enthalpies for H2 at the exposed Cu(II) site are significantly affected by pore metrics.  Introducing Me groups or using kinked ligands to create smaller pores can enhance the isosteric heat of adsorption and improve H2 adsorption.  However, although increasing the overlap of potential energy fields of pore walls increases the heat of H2 adsorption at low pressure, it may be detrimental to the overall adsorption capacity by reducing the pore vol.
Strong CO2 Binding in a Water-Stable, Triazolate-Bridged Metal-Organic Framework Functionalized with Ethylenediamine
Demessence, Aude; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Foo, Maw Lin; Long, Jeffrey R.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Reaction of CuCl2·2H2O with 1,3,5-tris(1H-1,2,3-triazol-5-yl)benzene (H3BTTri) in DMF at 100° generates the metal-org. framework H3[(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8(DMF)12]·7DMF·76H2O (1-DMF).  The sodalite-type structure of the framework consists of BTTri3--linked [Cu4Cl]7+ square clusters in which each CuII center has a terminal DMF ligand directed toward the interior of a large pore.  The framework exhibits a high thermal stability of up to 270°, as well as exceptional chem. stability in air, boiling water, and acidic media.  Following exchange of the guest solvent and bound DMF mols. for methanol to give 1-MeOH, complete desolvation of the framework at 180° generated H3[(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8] (1) with exposed CuII sites on its surface.  Following a previously reported protocol, ethylenediamine mols. were grafted onto these sites to afford 1-en, featuring terminal alkylamine groups.  The N2 adsorption isotherms indicate a redn. in the BET surface area from 1770 to 345 m2/g following grafting.  The H2 adsorption data at 77 K for 1 indicate a fully reversible uptake of 1.2% at 1.2 bar, while the CO2 isotherm at 195 K shows a maximal uptake of 90% at 1 bar.  Compared to 1, the alkylamine-functionalized framework 1-en exhibits a higher uptake of CO2 at 298 K and pressures up to ∼0.1 bar, as well as a higher CO2/N2 selectivity at all measured pressures.  Significantly, 1-en also exhibits an isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption of 90 kJ/mol, which is much higher than the 21 kJ/mol obsd. for 1.  This chemisorption interaction is the strongest reported to date for a metal-org. framework and points toward the potential utility of alkylamine-appended frameworks for the post-combustion capture of CO2 from low-pressure flue gas streams.
Structural Transformations and Adsorption of Fuel-Related Gases of a Structurally Responsive Nickel Phosphonate Metal-Organic Framework, Ni-STA-12

Miller, Stuart R.; Pearce, Gordon M.; Wright, Paul A.; Bonino, Francesca; Chavan, Sachin; Bordiga, Silvia; Margiolaki, Irene; Guillou, Nathalie; Ferey, Gerard; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The structure of the Ni N,N'-piperazinebismethylenephosphonate, Ni-STA-12 (St. Andrews porous material-12), was detd. in the hydrated (Ni2L·8H2O, L = O3PCH2NC4H8NCH2PO3), partially dehydrated (Ni2L·2H2O), and fully dehydrated (Ni2L) forms from high-resoln. synchrotron x-ray powder diffraction.  The framework structures of Ni2L·8H2O and Ni2L·2H2O are almost identical (R‾3, a 27.8342(1), c 6.2421(2) Å; R‾3, a 27.9144(1), c 6.1655(2) Å) with addnl. physisorbed H2O of the as-prepd. Ni-STA-12 present in an ordered H-bonded network in the channels.  Ab initio structure soln. of the fully dehydrated solid indicates it has changed symmetry to triclinic (P‾1, a 6.03475(5), b 14.9157(2), c 16.1572(2) Å, α 112.5721(7), β 95.7025(11), γ 96.4950(11)°) as a result of a topotactic structural rearrangement.  The fully dehydrated solid possesses permanent porosity with elliptical channels 8 Å × 9 Å in free diam.  The structural change results from the loss of H2O coordinated to the Ni cations, so that the Ni coordination changes from edge-sharing octahedral NiO5N to edge- and corner-sharing 5-fold NiO4N.  During this change, two out of three phosphonate groups rotate to become fully coordinated to Ni cations, leaving the remainder of the phosphonate groups coordinated to Ni cations by two O atoms and with a P=O bond projecting into the channels.  This transformation, which is completely reversible, causes substantial changes in both vibrational and electronic properties as shown by IR, Raman, and UV-visible spectroscopies.  Complementary adsorption, calorimetric, and IR studies of the probe adsorbates H2, CO, and CO2 reveal several distinct adsorption sites in the solid, which are attributed to their interactions with Ni cations which are weak Lewis acid sites, as well as with P=O groups that project into the pores.  At 304 K, the adsorption isotherms and enthalpies of adsorption on dehydrated Ni-STA-12 were measured for CO2 and CH4: Ni-STA-12 gives adsorption uptakes of CO2 of 2.5 mmol g-1 at 1 bar, an uptake ca.  10 Times that of CH4.
Cation-Triggered Drug Release from a Porous Zinc-Adeninate Metal-Organic Framework
An, Jihyun; Geib, Steven J.; Rosi, Nathaniel L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A porous anionic metal-org. framework, {[Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O]·8DMF·11H2O}n (bio-MOF-1; Had = adenine, H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid), constructed using adenine as a biomol. building block is described.  The porosity of this material is evaluated, its stability in biol. buffers is studied, and its potential as a material for controlled drug release is investigated.  Specifically, procainamide HCl is loaded into the pores of bio-MOF-1 using a simple cation exchange process.  Exogenous cations from biol. buffers are shown to affect the release of the adsorbed drug mols.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Factors affecting the polymorphic outcome of glycine crystals constrained on patterned substrates
Lee, Alfred Y.; Lee, In Sung; Myerson, Allan S.

The primary goal of crystn. process is to generate particles with controlled size, shape and solid form, and the desired chem. purity.  Many different types of approaches including mol. level strategies have been devised and employed to control the final structure of crystals.  One promising approach is the utilization of self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) as templates.  Recently, we reported that single glycine crystals can nucleate on patterned metallic square islands, with the size and morphol. of the particles controlled by the dimensions of the islands or the concn. of the soln.  Herein, the effect of the soln. concn. on the polymorphic outcome of glycine crystals confined to hydrophilic metallic islands is investigated.  Furthermore, we examine how variations in the solvent evapn. rate can impact the polymorph distribution of glycine.

Lin, Jian-Bin; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Xue, Wei; Xue, Dong-Xu; Chen, Xiao-Ming

Reactions of 3-(2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (Hdpt24) with Mn(OAc)2 under different conditions give two mononuclear complexes, [Mn(dpt24)2(MeOH)2] (1) and [Mn(dpt24)2(H2O)2]·6H2O (2), and three isomeric two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, α-[Mn(dpt24)2] (3a), β-[Mn(dpt24)2]·g (3b·g, g = DMF and H2O), and γ-[Mn(dpt24)2]·g (3c·g, g = toluene and MeOH).  Their structures were characterized by single-crystal and powder x-ray diffractions.  In these compds., four coordination sites of each octahedrally coordinated MnII ion are chelated by two dpt24 ligands in the trans and/or cis configurations.  While the two remaining coordination sites are occupied by solvent mols. in 1 and 2, they are occupied by pyridyl nitrogens from neighboring Mn(dpt24)2 units in 3, forming 4-connected 2-dimensional (4,4) networks.  The MnII ions in both 3a and 3b are uniquely chelated by dpt24 in the trans or cis configurations, resp., but Mn(dpt24)2 in 3c possesses both the trans and cis configurations.  The packing fashions of these (4,4) layers in the three isomers of 3 are also different, in which 3a has a close packing structure, while 3b exhibits unique 1-dimensional (1D) channels and 3c exhibits two distinct types of 1-dimensional channels. The gas and vapor sorption studies for porous 3b revealed interesting sorption behaviors.  Nitrogen adsorption for 3b was obsd. at 195 K rather than 77 K, demonstrating the temp.-controlled framework flexibility. NOTT-110 shows a high total H2 storage capacity of 7.62% at 55 bar and 77 K (8.5% at satn.) with a total volumetric capacity of 46.8 g L-1 at 55 bar and 77 K.

Biswas, Chaitali; Mukherjee, Pampa; Drew, Michael G. B.; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.; Clemente-Juan, Juan M.; Ghosh, Ashutosh

Three new polynuclear Cu(II) complexes of 2-picolinic acid (Hpic), {[Cu2(pic)3(H2O)]ClO4}n (1), {[Cu2(pic)3(H2O)]BF4}n (2), and [Cu2(pic)3(H2O)2(NO3)]n (3), were synthesized by reaction of the metalloligand [Cu(pic)2] with the corresponding Cu(II) salts.  The compds. were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses and variable-temp. magnetic measurements.  Compds. 1 and 2 are isomorphous and crystallize in the triclinic system with space group P‾1, while 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/n.  The structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 are constructed by fish backbone chains through syn-anti (equatorial-equatorial) carboxylate bridges, which are linked to one another by syn-anti (equatorial-axial) carboxylate bridges, giving rise to a rectangular grid-like two-dimensional net.  Complex 3 is formed by alternating chains of syn-anti carboxylate-bridged Cu(II) atoms, which are linked together by strong H bonds involving coordinated nitrate ions and H2O mols. and uncoordinated O atoms from carboxylate groups.  The different coordination ability of the anions along with their involvement in the H-bonding network seems to be responsible for the difference in the final polymeric structures.  Variable-temp. (2-300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurement shows weak ferromagnetic coupling for all three complexes that were fitted with a fish backbone model developed for 1 and 2 (J = 1.74 and 0.99 cm-1; J' = 0.19 and 0.25 cm-1, resp.) and an alternating chain model for 3 (J = 1.19 cm-1 and J' = 1.19 cm-1).
Ferric ion sequestering agents. 17. Macrobicyclic iron(III) sequestering agents
McMurry, Thomas J.; Hosseini, Mir Wais; Garrett, Thomas M.; Hahn, F. Ekkehardt; Reyes, Zelideth E.; Raymond, Kenneth N.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The synthesis of a series of macrobicyclic triscatechol ligands is reported.  These ligands are designed to complex Fe(III) or other high-valent transition metals and involve a high degree of preorganization of the metal binding site.  The 1st structural characterization of an Fe(III) triscatechoylamide complex is reported, and reveals an unprecedented trigonal-prismatic coordination geometry at the metal center.  This coordination polyhedron results from a minimization of ligand-conformation strain and the formation of 6 strong internal H bonds of the ligand.  The 3 catechol rings and their conjugated amide groups are coplanar and form a triskelion in which the dihedral angle between the catechol plane and the plane of the Fe and 2 ligating O atoms is 30.79(12)°.  The key step in the synthesis of these ligands is the coupling of a tripodal amine capping subunit via a triple amide bond-forming reaction with the acid chloride of a terephthalic acid in which the catechol O atoms are protected by Me groups.  A cyclic voltammogram of the Fe complex of the ligand in which 1 capping group is a 1,3,5-triamino deriv. of mesitylene and the 2nd cap is tris(2-aminoethyl)amine is reversible, with a 1-electron potential of -0.92 V at high pH, corresponding to a ratio of the formation consts. for Fe(III)/Fe(II) of 1028.6.
Dielectric properties of cholesteric liquid crystals
Shaw, D. G.; Kauffman, J. W.
Physica Status Solidi A:  Applied Research

The dielec. const. and loss of the 3 cholesteric liq. crystals, cholesteryl acetate (CA), propionate (SP), and stearate (CS), in the solid, liq. crystal, and isotropic liq. states are presented as functions of temp. and frequency.  These data provide evidence for the existence of 2 different cholesteric liq.-crystal states for CA and CS, one on heating and one on cooling.  The liq.-crystal state on heating behaves dielec. like a solid and on cooling behaves dielec. like a liq.  The dielec. const. on cooling is much greater than that on heating.  The liq.-crystal state of CP, on the other hand, behaves dielec. like a liq. on both heating and cooling.  The permanent and induced dipole moments and the orientational and instantaneous polarizations are calcd. for the 3 esters.  The instantaneous polarizations depend strongly on the ester chain lengthand are much greater than the orientational polarizations.  Both the permanent dipole and the orientational polarizations are independent of ester chain length.

Solubility profiles of poly(ethylene glycol)/solvent systems, I: Qualitative comparison of solubility parameter approaches

Soly. of systems involving four different mol. wts. of poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) in THF, chloroform, dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), methanol and water were studied by different algorithmic approaches as the math. application of the "like dissolves like" principle.  In this study, the soly. parameters and their components for PEG and solvents were evaluated by using of at. group contribution methods; Small, van Krevelen-Hoftyzer (VKH), Hoy and Breitkreutz methods, resp.  Then their 2-dimensional graphs (Bagley, Henry and Hoernschemeyer diagrams) and 3-dimensional graph (Hansen diagram) were drawn by creating the soly. profiles of the polymer in selected solvents.  The dissolving capability of these solvents was discussed.  In addn. the soly. parameters were calcd. by use of the van der Waals vol. in the selected mol. or repeating unit of the polymer instead of the molar volume which is used in at. group contribution methods (Askadskii approach).  Surface tensions of the polymer and solvent systems were calcd. with this method and soly. criteria of PEG were explained after a serial calcn. steps.  In addn., influence of mol. wt. of PEG on soly. was also analyzed.  As a consequence of algorithmic calcns., THF was detd. as the best solvent whereas water is the weakest solvent for polymer/solvent systems.
Triethylborane-Induced Bromine Atom-Transfer Radical Addition in Aqueous Media: Study of the Solvent Effect on Radical Addition Reactions
Yorimitsu, Hideki; Shinokubo, Hiroshi; Matsubara, Seijiro; Oshima, Koichiro; Omoto, Kiyoyuki; Fujimoto, Hiroshi

A mixt. of Et bromoacetate and 1-octene was treated with triethylborane in water at ambient temp. to provide Et 4-bromodecanoate in good yield.  The bromine atom-transfer radical addn. in benzene was not satisfactory.  The addn. proceeded smoothly in polar solvents such as DMF and DMSO, protic solvents such as 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol and 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoro-2-propanol, and aq. media.  Ab initio calcns. were conducted to reveal the origin of the solvent effect of water in the addn. reaction.  The polar effect of solvents, which is judged by the dielec. const., on the transition states in the bromine atom-transfer and radical addn. steps is moderately important.  Calcns. show that a polar solvent tends to lower the relative energies of the transition states.  The coordination of a carbonyl group to a proton in a protic solvent, like a Lewis acid, would also increase the efficiency of the propagation.  Safety: triethylborane may ignite spontaneously when exposed to air.
Constant composition study of crystal growth of dicalcium phosphate dihydrate.  The influence of polyphosphates, phosphonates, and phytate

The influence of inhibitors of varying functional groups on the crystal growth of CaHPO4.2H2O (DCPD) on DCPD seed crystals at pH 6.00 and 37° was studied using the const. compn. technique.  The inhibitors studied included Na pyrophosphate, Na hexametaphosphate (SHMP), nitrilotris(methylenephosphonic acid) (NTMP), 1-hydroxyethylidene-1,1-diphosphonic acid (HEDP), ethylenediaminetetra(methylenephosphonic acid) (ETMP) hexamethylenediaminetetra(methylenephosphonic acid) (HMDP) and myoinositol hexaphosphoric acid (phytic acid).  The effects of these inhibitors on the growth kinetics were studied at several inhibitor concns.  The retarding effect of these inhibitors is discussed in relation to Ca-inhibitor complex formation on the DCPD seed crystals and the structural features of the inhibitor mols.  The fit of the Langmuir adsorption to exptl. data supports a mechanism of inhibition through mol. adsorption of the inhibitor ions on the surface of growing crystals.  Based upon the kinetic data, the overall order of inhibitors effectiveness is ETMP > HMDP > phytic acid > hexametaphosphate > HEDP > pyrophosphate.
Mechanistic and Kinetic Studies of Crystallization of Birnessite
Luo, Jian; Zhang, Qiuhua; Suib, Steven L.

Kinetic and mechanistic features have been studied for the crystn. of birnessite in aq. systems via different synthesis methods: the oxidn. of Mn2+, redn. of MnO4-, and redox reaction between Mn2+ and MnO4-.  For oxidn. methods, a topotactical conversion from Mn(OH)2 to birnessite via feitknechtite (β-MnOOH) is obsd.  In redn. methods, birnessite evolves from the initially produced amorphous manganese oxide (AMO gel).  For redox methods, both mechanisms exist, with the latter prevailing.  A liq. mechanism is proposed to describe the redn. and redox synthesis, which comprises three stages: an induction period, a fast crystn. period, and a steady-state period.  The redox method is accompanied by the formation and phase transformation of feitknechtite to birnessite.  A method combining IR and XRD quantitation is proposed to detect nuclei in the induction period.  Crystn. rates and apparent energies of activation of crystn. for redn. and redox methods are detd.
